meta.title: Q4 2008 Earnings Call - Rio Tinto and Chinalco Joint Venture Agreement

participants.participant: Xiao Yaqing, Executive Committee Secretary and President, Chinalco

plist.p: Well, good morning to all of you here in London, good evening to all those who're joining us from Australia. In fact, we have people in a number of different locations this time. And I hope that in the Q&A that follows, we will be able to do justice to all of you.

Today's presentation will cover both the announcement of what I think is a landmark transaction in our corporate history, as well as Rio Tinto's 2008 full year results. The transaction with Chinalco announced today will reposition Rio Tinto both financially in the medium term and strategically in the longer term. It offers significant value to shareholders now and competitive advantage for the future of the business.
We're delighted to have President, Xiao; and Vice President, Liu of Chinalco with us in this presentation today. Welcome to London to both of you.
Tom is also here with me in London; and Guy Elliott, CFO is joining us from Melbourne, and Guy can see you very clearly. You are hearing us okay?
Very well. Thank you.

Thank you very much. So the schedule is that we will present first on our recommended transaction with Chinalco followed by a transaction specific Q&A session. We'll then take a short 10-minute break, after which we will present the highlights version of our usual financial results also with accompanying Q&A.

We are very pleased to announce today that Rio Tinto has agreed to enter into a pioneering strategic partnership with Chinalco. The proposed partnership will entail the investment by Chinalco of U.S. $19.5 billion in our company through a combination of asset level investments and the issue of Rio Tinto convertible bonds.

The asset investment of 12.3 billion will occur through the creation of three commodity based joint ventures in aluminium, copper, and iron ore, while the balance of 7.2 billion will be gained through the subscription by Chinalco for the convertible bonds to which I referred.

The proposed transaction will deliver multiple benefits to Rio Tinto. Firstly, at premium values, and we will discuss that at some length, it will substantially strengthen Rio Tinto's balance sheet, addressing simultaneously both the near term liquidity requirements and our overall level of indebtedness.

Secondly, strategic flexibility will be restored as the company is able to act on compelling investment opportunities through the economic cycle. Thirdly, the transaction will create a unique partnership between Rio Tinto and Chinalco with the ability to capitalize strongly on emerging trends in global resources.

Specifically, Rio Tinto's traditional strength as a leading diversified miner will be complemented through access to Chinalco's unique insights, relationships, and capabilities. Taken in total, we believe this partnership will deliver an outstanding value for our shareholders.

It's important, I think, to understand that today's announcement is the culmination of a series of engagements between Chinalco and Rio Tinto, since Chinalco's original investment in Rio Tinto back in February 2008. At that time, we said that we would seek value-creating opportunities to work together; and today's announcement is testament to the great potential that exists in exploring areas of mutual cooperation.

Following extensive consideration of the strategic options available to Rio Tinto, the Boards have unanimously concluded that the opportunity offered by this partnership is superior to other identified options and offers greater medium-term certainty and longer-term value for shareholders. We believe the transaction will secure for Rio Tinto a leadership position in global resources.

The transaction begins a pioneering strategic partnership that combines the very best of the developed and the developing world. It is no surprise, I think, to anybody listening to this presentation that the developing world is increasingly important to the resources sector.

A fact we believe the current global financial crisis is only likely to underscore. In that context, we believe this partnership will uniquely position Rio Tinto within the sector by allowing us to benefit from Chinalco's market insight, strong Chinese relationships and capabilities.

Chinalco, and I am sure, President Xiao will speak to this, will benefit from exposure to Rio Tinto's expertise in managing and operating long life, large, world class resources. As I mentioned earlier, the transaction is value enhancing for Rio Tinto's shareholders on a number of levels. Chinalco's cash investment provides us with balance sheet strength and flexibility to pursue our long-term strategy right through the economic cycle.

Importantly, this cash has been raised at a substantial premium to current market valuations, and Guy will in his presentation take you through this. I think it is a rare if not unique achievement in today's current financial environment.

Rio Tinto's standards of governance and first-rate operational practice will continue as before. At the corporate level and within the commodity joint ventures, strong governance structures will ensure continued commercial focus and independence in all decision making.

Rio Tinto will run the business according to its established business principles. Current practices will continue at all facilities. And I'll say a little bit more about that in a moment. For these reasons, the Board intends unanimously to recommend this transaction to shareholders.

Let me provide some color regarding the two components of the proposed transaction. First, three commodity based joint ventures will be established in aluminium, copper, and iron ore. Each will contain certain Rio Tinto operations, in which Chinalco will take a minority or joint venture interest.

The specifics of the operations involved and Chinalco's interest are shown in the table. Tom is going to go through each of the ventures in more detail later. But I think, it's important to highlight that in all cases, where Rio Tinto is already the operator, Rio Tinto will maintain operational and management control of the assets within the ventures. The total investment by Chinalco in these ventures will be $12.3 billion.

The second component is in the investment in subordinated convertible bonds, and Guy will describe the key features of these bonds in more detail later. But several aspects are set out here. Note in particular that the bonds are convertible at substantial premia to today's share price, and that the coupon rate of 9% on the plc bonds and 9.5% on the Limited bonds are very competitive in today's credit environment.

If they are fully converted, Chinalco's interest in Rio Tinto will total 18%, including the 9.3% which was purchased in February 2008. The two components of the transaction are internally-conditional and complementary, and assist in ensuring that future partnership co-operation is maximized. Accordingly, we will be seeking approval for both components, it is not an either/or proposal.

Underpinning a proposed partnership is Rio Tinto's long-standing recognition of the crucial role China is playing in the global economy. We all know the headlines, but the implication of the scale of China's contribution to world economic growth should not be underestimated.
For decades, only a quarter of global GDP was contributed by the developing world; and China, as you can see in the left hand columns, was only a fraction of that.

By 2025, the developing world will contribute more than half of global GDP, and China alone will contribute around 20%. This is a profound change that will inevitably lead to a transformation in political, economic, and social dynamics.

The pioneering strategic partnership we announced today is a continuation of Rio Tinto's relationships with China. And it provides us, I think, with an unrivaled competitive position in one of the world's key markets.

Both Chinalco and Rio Tinto have agreed that this partnership must be built on strong independent governance structures ensuring continuity of strategy and continued commercial focus. At the corporate level, Independent Non-Executive Directors will continue to comprise a majority of the Rio Tinto Boards.

Chinalco will be entitled to nominate two Non-Executive Directors to complement the existing Boards, one of whom will be independent under recognized corporate governance standards. These appointments will be subject to approval by the Board's current Nominations Committee. These specifics and other principles designed to ensure continuity of independent and commercial decision-making have been included in a comprehensive relationship agreement executed between the companies.

The commodity joint ventures will also incorporate strong governance mechanisms. Each will have a Strategic Alliance Committee responsible for setting high-level direction. Voting rights on each committee will reflect the economic interest of each party. And given Chinalco's interests are a minority in each case, ultimate control will remain with Rio Tinto, where Rio Tinto is the operator of the relevant asset, existing operational arrangements will be maintained, including a commitment to save sustainable and ethical business practices, which our new colleagues from Chinalco are fully supportive of.
And I think that is a good moment for me to hand over, and once again to welcome President Xiao of Chinalco to speak to you. President Xiao?
Ladies and gentlemen, as you know, we made an investment into 9% of Rio Tinto last year, and from then long discussions between the two companies started.

The transaction just outlined by Chairman Skinner, I think, is a very good testimony to our confidence over the longer term in Rio Tinto. We firmly believe this transaction is also going to bring a lot of opportunities for Chinalco, both in China and elsewhere in the world. Also we anticipate a better return on our investment.

Given that the partnership is established both at a shareholding – at a corporate level and at asset level, we believe that this partnership would bring – will bring opportunities for additional value creation for both parties.

Chinalco is a leading diversified resources company in China. We are ranked number three, number four, and number five in terms of the production of alumina, aluminium, and fabricated aluminium products in the world.

We're expanding our businesses both in terms of commodities and in terms of geography. We've made significant investments in Australia and Peru, for example, recently. Compared to Rio Tinto, Chinalco is a relatively young company. We were formally established only back in 2001, but over the years – over the past few years we've managed to grow very fast.

Expanding on our core competence over aluminium, we have been able to expand into other commodities such as titanium, copper, and other rare metals. We are also very focused on environmental protection and our corporate responsibilities toward the host communities, therefore we enjoy very good relations with all communities we work in.

We believe this is a major step in developing our international presence in getting the company more familiar with best practices and standards worldwide, and as such to be able to establish cooperation with world leaders in the sector. Despite the fact that we are a state-owned company, I'd like to emphasize that we are run completely independently and commercially. All our decisions related to marketing, production and capital expenditure is made by the management team independently.

I believe that this investment is going to yield a very attractive financial return over the longer term. As Tom and Guy will elaborate upon the details of the transaction, I will not delve too much on those, but I would just like to say that given the expertise of the management teams involved here, we are fully confident that this transaction is only a start that will lead to many more opportunities in the future. Thank you.

Thank you, President Xiao. We're announcing a transaction with Chinalco today, which is consistent with our long-established corporate strategy. Rio Tinto remains fully focused on maximizing shareholder value by firstly developing and operating a portfolio of long life, low cost, large scale assets, by maintaining and building industry-leading operational capability, and of course by identifying and capturing great opportunities to create value whenever and wherever they may come.

Our strategic partnership with Chinalco complements this strategy in four different ways. First, it does strongly support shareholder value by raising capital at a substantial premium to current market prices ensuring short-term financial uncertainty is eliminated. It provides us with the flexibility to take advantage – full advantage of our unique asset base. This includes reducing the capital constraints that might otherwise limit our ability to execute our long-term growth strategy, and being better positioned to respond when the recovery does come.

We ensure funding remains for new investment opportunities without lowering the high standards we've set as part of our rigorous capital appraisal processes. And finally, it does position the company to benefit from the trends that are continuing to emerge in the resource industry, particularly driven by China.

President Xiao has just described an independent commercial and successful resources company, possessing qualities which we believe make it the ideal partner for Rio Tinto. Generating an outstanding track record of growth and value creating investments, Chinalco successfully consolidated the Chinese aluminum sector. And now it's extending that footprint outside its core sector and geography.

Starting with the steep towers of China, the fastest growing market in the world for our commodities, Chinalco has developed a strong position in developing countries. Chinalco's access to strong financial support has been instrumental in its ability to participate in new opportunities for growth. In addition to this impressive business performance and competitive position, Chinalco's values and objectives are closely aligned with our own. Both Chinalco and Rio Tinto operate through governance process designed to foster independent commercial behavior, and we share a commitment for maintaining the appropriate balance between excellent financial returns for our shareholders and sustainable development for the stakeholders and communities we work in.

Our management teams are both experienced and professional, and we are committed to openness, including our desire to benefit from transparent capital markets. And finally, it's worth reminding ourselves that joint ventures with major Japanese and Chinese companies have been a key part of our business for over 20 years. The 19.5 billion of cash generated for Rio Tinto addresses our liquidity position, provides balance sheet strength, and operational and strategic flexibility.

A portion of proceeds will be used to meet our commitment made on December 10, 2008 to repay U.S. $10 billion of debt by the end of 2009. Cash will remain after this repayment is made, which could be applied to either further debt repayments or for selective investment. Above all, the critical point is this provides the company with flexibility. And these proceeds provided by Chinalco also underpin our progressive dividend policy and the maintenance of the 2008 full year dividend at the 2007 level.

At this point, I want to talk in more detail about how this partnership will assist Rio Tinto to the greatest extent possible from important trends in the resources sector. Every aspect of the resources sector is being – becoming increasingly influenced by the developing world, and China in particular. Demand growth for commodity market will be driven by rapidly growing economies, such as China.

New Tier 1 resources will increasingly be found in emerging geographies, and the resources sector require the geological and geopolitical expertise to secure access to them. In addition, most activity in emerging markets will require a broader range of project execution skills. And finally rapid economic development, together with traditional and continued high savings rates means the developing world is now an important new source of capital for all companies, not simply in the resources sector.

Over the next decade, access to developing world markets and resources, execution skills and finance will be the difference between the winners and the losers in our sector. There should be little doubt that irrespective of the current economic crisis, we're probably facing a long-term rebalancing of the global economy, with the developing world and China playing an ever greater role based upon fundamental trends of demographics and industrialization. This is not new for Rio Tinto.

It should be recalled that when we established our first iron ore joint venture with China back in 1987, we were the first to export iron ore to China in 1973. We were also the first to recognize and respond to the structural upturn in the Chinese economic growth by our early expansion in 2003 of our iron ore production in the Pilbara.

So Rio Tinto was early to recognize and welcome the growing participation of China in the global economy and the opportunities this presents. We do believe that China's role in driving global commodity demand will continue to grow into the future.

The forecast on this chart show China's share of total demand, and the demand growth in key commodities. Of course, this is based upon December and January data that include an assessment of the impact of the unfolding global economic downturn. And it clearly shows the underlying economic forces at work in China means this trend will not be derailed by the current economic conditions.

The benefits to Rio Tinto of increasing our expertise in and access to Chinese markets is obvious. For us volume growth must come from reaching new customers. Our new customers will overwhelmingly be located in China. A partnership with Chinalco positions Rio Tinto to benefit from these industry trends. Rio Tinto's knowledge of Chinese markets will be increased through access to Chinalco's insights regarding supply and demand dynamics, and the power of potential market impact of government policies, stimulation and actions.

This is particularly useful at a time when the Chinese government's stimulus package will be a key driver of global economic performance. Chinalco's assistance will be invaluable as we work to secure new resources in China, a country that's never been fully explored using modern exploration techniques. In addition, Chinalco's expertise, experience and connections in developing nations will assist Rio Tinto to access and develop new resources around the world. Chinalco's skills will add to Rio Tinto's own in developing new Tier 1 assets.

Maybe let's give a few examples. First, Chinalco will share its deep experience and knowledge of logistics in emerging countries. Second, Rio Tinto plans to leverage Chinalco's access to Chinese project development and execution capabilities. And third, Rio Tinto will have the benefit of new technologies to be developed in partnership with Chinalco on a commercial basis only. And finally, Chinalco will assist Rio Tinto to secure capital for major projects or acquisitions.

Both Rio Tinto and Chinalco are very confident that we can work together to turn these potential benefits into value for Rio Tinto shareholders. In fact, we're quickly taking specific actions to realize this value. Rio Tinto and Chinalco today have announced joint initiatives with some immediate benefits. And they include an agreement to access the potential for joint exploration in China; a memorandum of understanding regarding possible joint development at Simandou iron ore province in Guinea; and the development protocols to share and jointly develop human resources, especially Rio Tinto's operational expertise and Chinalco's sales and marketing personnel.

And finally meetings have already been held by senior Rio Tinto's executives and Chinese banking officials to discuss potential opportunities for project-based finance. These have been constructive. We are very confident that real access to capital will be achieved.

We firmly believe these are initial examples of how the relationship between Rio Tinto and Chinalco can yield benefits to both parties, providing an indication of things to come. Chinalco's asset stakes purchase of course means they will receive portion of earnings from the relevant assets going forward.

On an attributable EBITDA basis and using second half 2008 data to capture the impact of the steep falls in traded commodity prices in the second half of last year, the attributable EBITDA acquired by Chinalco in the transaction represents about 8% of Rio Tinto's total attributable EBITDA. And this is consistent with our view of the NPV contribution made by the stakes transferred.

Turning now to the details of the commodity joint ventures. In aluminum, as you both – as you already know companies have existing interest – both companies have existing interests in aluminum in Queensland. And through this transaction, Chinalco's investments will be at Weipa, 30% of the total economic interest with Rio Tinto at 70; at Yarwun, 50% for both parties; and just under 50% of Rio's existing interest in Boyne and Gladstone Power Station.
Taken together, Chinalco's proposed interest in these four facilities had they been applicable from 1st of July 2008 would represent about 4% of Rio Tinto Alcan's second half 2008 EBITDA.

Apart from these investments in current operating businesses, Chinalco and Rio Tinto anticipate pursuing a number of further opportunities through the join venture, including the potential to link more closely with the adjacent Arukun lease, and Weipa and nearby resources as appropriate.

The joint venture with Chinese refining opportunities subject to Rio Tinto's usual commercial assessment procedures. The development of our human resources through secundments and exchanges, and finally the use of technology developed by the join venture at every locations operated by Rio Tinto and Chinalco.

Rio Tinto and Chinalco have agreed to a number of specific marketing arrangements for the joint venture's bauxite resources. Once Rio Tinto's system requirements are satisfied and those of existing customers, a portion of the existing production at Weipa will be marketed by a new joint venture marketing company, including the Chinese customers.

Marketing of this other bauxite will be managed by Rio Tinto on behalf of the joint venture. The joint venture will also negotiate at arm's length a multi-year commitment to supply Chinalco's allocation to Yarwun.

The potential value with the combination of Rio Tinto's assets and skills with Chinalco's acknowledged aluminium expertise is outstanding. For copper, Chinalco's investment will secure economic interest in Escondida with just over 15% of the total Escondida economic interest; at Kennecott Utah Copper with 25, with Rio, 75%; and at Grasberg, with 12% of the total economic interest, as you know through the metal strip which is imbedded within the Grasberg venture.

Taken together and assuming their application had been from the 1st of July 2008 by way of example, these interests would have represented 36% of the copper croup's EBITDA for the second half of 2008. And of course, these shares are after the economic interests of our joint venture partners are taken into consideration.

The joint venture also envisions Chinalco's joint participation in future projects, and these include Chinalco's investment has also secured an economic interest in 30% of La Granja in Peru. And Rio Tinto and Chinalco will also discuss the potential to bring Chinalco's Peru projects interest other joint venture. While current market arrangements remain unaffected, we would anticipate the parties using Chinalco's skills to market La Granja production into China.

Let's now talk about iron ore. In iron ore, Chinalco's investment will secure a 15% share in the wholly owned businesses within Hamersley Iron. And had this joint venture been in effect from the 1st of July 2008, this share would represent about 10% of the iron group – iron ore group, product group EBITDA for the second half of 2008. Chinalco and Rio Tinto have agreed to consider a number of future opportunities including the potential for joint participation and future expansions of Hamersley Iron's production and consideration of how best to jointly participate in the Simandou iron ore project in Guinea.

In addition, Rio Tinto and Chinalco will form a jointly owned sales company, managed by Rio Tinto iron ore to market 30% of Hamersley Iron output in China. Rio Tinto will be the ultimate marketer of this product on behalf of this company similar and consistent with the approach used in our other joint ventures in the Pilbara.

Chinalco's assistance to market Hamersley Iron ore product into China strengthens Rio Tinto's already strong iron ore position enormously. Chinalco is investing in 100%-owned assets of Hamersley Iron, which include in addition to the mines, our two ports and associated rail infrastructure. These are core elements at the Hamersley operations in WA, and will create a completely new joint venture. It is important to recognize this joint venture sits outside of the other Rio Tinto iron ore joint ventures in the Pilbara, such as Hope Downs, Channar, and Robe River.

We know how to manage joint ventures and have decades of experience in running joint ventures with competitors, as well as our Japanese and Chinese customers. This is an established part of the mining industry and has always been a source of funds for future mineral development.

Now let's close by recapping the core benefits of the proposed transaction. First, it raises capital at a substantial premium to current market valuations. Guy will go into this in more detail in a minute, but I'd note at this point that there are several aspects at the Board for asset level investments and the convertible bonds that are demonstrably favorable. Particularly when considered in light of current economic conditions and the avenue being used by almost all others to raise capital. I believe, this demonstrates the optionality, the suite of Tier 1 assets can give a company both in good times and in bad.

Second, Chinalco's cash investments eliminates near-term uncertainty regarding Rio Tinto's financial position by greatly strengthening our balance sheet. We are proceeding with our previously announced non-core asset divestment program at a pace which provides best value for Rio Tinto's shareholders.

Third, the transaction provides Rio Tinto with the flexibility to undertake investments throughout the cycle. And as far as today's announcement, we can confirm that the Yarwun, Kestrel and Clermont expansions will proceed, and work will commence to facilitate an expansion in Hail Creek. In addition, we are continuing preparatory activities in respect to Pilbara 320, but we do need to wait for some meaningful and credible signs of economic recovery. Above and beyond these specific announcements, we have restored our ability to pursue opportunities as they arise. This transaction will alleviate about 2,000 job reductions, including project – contractors and projects in Australia, which would otherwise have been difficult to advance.

Finally, as I have explained this transaction creates a strategic partnership with an unparalleled ability to benefit from emerging industry trends. This is about long-term strategy. We were also able to point to several tangible examples today. We have agreed to jointly pursue possible exploration opportunities in China, and jointly consider how Simandou might be best developed. Further China's – Chinalco's relationship within China have already facilitated the introduction of key Rio Tinto executives to Chinese policy banks, which may lead to further access to Chinese funding.
With that I'd like to now turn over to Guy in Australia, who'll run through some of the metrics for the transaction.

Thank you, Tom. When entering a transaction like this, the Board has to weigh out all comparable alternatives, and this we've done in considerable detail. A large number of options have been reviewed and value has always remained the paramount consideration for the Board in reaching its conclusions.

Overall, we've concluded that this package from Chinalco, given its scale, valuation premium and strategic benefits, represents the most value creating means for the Group to meet its financial commitments. We've talked a lot today about the generation of US$19.5 billion in cash for Rio Tinto's shareholders through this transaction. But I'd like to explore with you some of the quantitative metrics which demonstrate why we concluded this transaction was in the best interest of our shareholders.

I should highlight at the outset that quantitative comparisons during a time of severely dislocated debt and equity markets needs to be made with due caution. With this in mind, the overall transaction can best be broken down into three components, which can be compared quite readily to objective external data. The prices achieved in relation to asset investments, the price premium at which the convertible bonds convert, and the coupon rate payable on the convertible bonds.

In each case, we believe that the outcome achieved is a favorable result, particularly given the context in which this transaction takes place. This reflects both Chinalco's recognition of the quality of Rio Tinto's assets and its confidence in the Group's prospects.

The parties negotiated an agreement for Chinalco to invest in a number of assets for proceeds totaling $12.3 billion. In order to provide transparency on the value inherent in this transaction, we are providing an asset-by-asset breakdown of the value as shown here. This will enable you to undertake a rigorous analysis of the transaction fundamentals. We believe that these valuations speak for themselves.

This transaction is the best overall package for shareholders for three key reasons. Firstly, the commercial terms of the transaction, both in the asset sales and the convertible bonds represent premium value.

Secondly, the proceeds of the $19.5 billion completely meet Rio Tinto's financial obligations over the next two years. While the sum may appear large, it definitely removes – it definitively removes any financial concerns that may arise should the downturn turn out to be more protracted.

Finally, the transaction restores flexibility to the Group, by allowing us to invest through the cycle and it provides strategic benefits in the form of a deep relationship with a key player in our largest market.

Chinalco's investments in the commodity joint ventures are at a premium to current implied asset values as measured by Rio Tinto's enterprise value. Simply put, Chinalco has paid 18% of Rio Tinto's current market enterprise value for an 8% share of EBITDA.

These numbers are based on second half 2008 earnings and market enterprise value is calculated using share prices on the 30th of January, 2009, prior to our release disclosing that we are in discussion with Chinalco. This represents a premium of 124% to our current market enterprise value.
On the same basis of calculation, the premium to market capitalization is 287%. The equivalent share price implied by the investments in the assets is £58 or A$163 per share.

Now the next slide presents a number of details regarding the convertible bonds. Rio Tinto plans to issue two tranches of subordinated convertible bonds totaling $7.2 billion. The first tranche convertible at $45 per share will contribute $3.1 billion in funds, while the second tranche convertible at $60 per share will contribute $4.1 billion.

The coupon is 9% for bonds issued out of PLC and 9.5% for bonds issued out of limited. The bonds are subordinated to other Rio Tinto debt and carry no voting rights until conversion. The bonds have been structured with the aim of achieving 50% equity credit from the rating agencies.

Standard & Poor's has indicated, subject to satisfactory final documents and the amount to be issued relative to the capital of the Group, that the bonds would be eligible for intermediate or 50% equity credit. The amount of equity credit is, of course, subject to final conformation by the agencies.

The bonds mature after six years with an option after seven years for Rio Tinto to redeem the bond. After this time, Rio Tinto has the flexibility to refinance the bond to take advantage of credit market conditions. Chinalco has the right to convert the bonds at any time. If fully converted, Chinalco's interest in Rio Tinto will increase from the current 9.3% to 18%. Chinalco's interest in Rio Tinto Limited will be 14.9% and in Rio Tinto Plc 19%.

Now regardless of whether you are considering Plc or Limited, the conversion premium secured in respect of the convertible bonds that Rio Tinto proposes to issue in respect to this transaction are very high. Based on Rio Tinto's share prices on the 30th of January, as I said in the last trading day prior to our announcement that we were in discussions with Chinalco, that conversion premium secured range from a low of 68% to a high of 176% above the share price. Based on the historical records that we've been able to find, this is very favorable. As a result, this premium can be seen as a strong signal regarding Chinalco's confidence in the valuation potential of Rio Tinto's assets and prospects.

Given the size of the convertible note proposed to be issued to Chinalco, the fact that it's subordinated to all other Group debt and the attractive terms of the issue, one could quite reasonably expect the coupon to be priced very substantially higher than the current BBB senior corporate bond deal of around 8.5%.

Comparable securities issued recently have had higher coupons coupled with much lower conversion prices relative to market. Of course, those of you who are familiar with the state of the corporate bond markets at the moment would be aware that an issue of this size would be unlikely, if not impossible, to perform. The convertible bonds represent very competitive financing terms for Rio Tinto, particularly in current markets and given their subordination.
As it's customary in this type of transaction, we've agreed a break fee of 1%, which will become payable if the Board changed its recommendation that shareholders should approve this transaction.

There's also an exclusivity arrangement in which both parties have agreed not to solicit competing third-party proposals prior to completion. These are inline with market practice and sound fiduciary principles.

There are a number of preconditions before the proposed transaction can close. These are the following. First of all, Rio Tinto's shareholders must approve the transaction. This is through a joint electorate vote of Rio Tinto Plc and Limited shareholders at which a simple majority vote in favor must be achieved.

Secondly, government approvals must be secured including foreign investment reviews as appropriate. Rio Tinto has already begun a cooperative process to ensure that these reviews occur in an open, efficient, and timely basis.

Thirdly, Chinalco must finalize their own financing arrangements, which they must have committed to do by the 31st of March 2009. We would anticipate closing the transaction late in the second quarter or early in the third quarter of 2009.
So with that, let me hand you back to Paul.

Okay. Thank you very much indeed. Before I just finally recap the benefits of this proposed transaction, I want to speak very briefly about the benefits of the partnership for those countries in which we currently operate and those which we will operate in future.

The proposed alliance sets the platform for relationships with China for the both broader and deeper than today. We feel this partnership will provide examples for others who seek investment and trade relationships with Chinese firms, not only in the resources sector, but in the commercial world more generally.

The partnership also represents a very strong link to potential resource sector funding. It introduces a new source of capital at a time when investment capital from traditional partners is scarce. In this way, our stakeholder countries will be able to benefit from continued reinvestment throughout the cycle, and in turn, from greater economic growth in the next upswing.

We believe access and insight to the Chinese market will assist our stakeholder countries to retain their global market share of resource production. Every new customer Rio Tinto supplies, generates wealth not only for our shareholders, but for the countries in which we operate. Similarly, it increases the potential for firms to work more closely with Chinese firms on joint initiatives of common interest, clean coal, for example, would be something to think of in those terms.

In summary then, you have seen the proposed transaction delivers a comprehensive package of benefits reaffirming Rio Tinto's strength and potential. It strengthens our balance sheet. It gives us the flexibility to understand high value strategic growth at all points of the cycle. And it positions us at the forefront of industry trends involving China and the developing world.

President Xiao said to you that in Chinalco we found an excellent partner, and your investment is a clear vote of confidence in our company's strength, growth prospects and outlook. We expect to be able to execute the transaction within the timeframe that is reasonable for all stakeholders. We will, of course, be asking for the approval of both our Plc and Limited shareholders, who will receive the Board's strong and unanimous recommendation.

So at this point, thank you. And we'll start some question and answers. Nigel Jones, who is head of Investor Relations is going to coordinate this given that we have people coming from different places, and Nigel, we'll ask you to manage the flow of questions.
Let's start off with people in this auditorium. I can see questions at back. If you just gave your name and institution please.

Sure. Thanks, Nigel. Rob Clifford, Deutsche Bank. Two questions; one is quite simple, would you be doing this transaction if you weren't so – if your balance sheet wasn't so distressed? And the second question probably for Guy, can – for the assets under consideration, can he just articulate which ones will be that Chinalco will take an equity stake in, and which ones will have a strategic alliance note associated with it?

Well, on the why-now, clearly this proposition does a number of things. It deals with the financing challenges the company has had, but it is I think on a look forward basis a great source of economic opportunity and value creation.

We have been engaged over quite a lot long period in discussion with our friends from Chinalco, and we are attracted to this opportunity as much by what it will do to create future value as it's doing to deal with financing challenges. So, it's something which in its aggregate deals I think very well with all the issues.

So I think even if we were not in a position of having to address balance sheet issues, the fact that we are moving through a period, which could not quite a long time of major economic challenge in the world, the idea of striking such a partnership at this time is very appealing.
